user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CountSemGetInfo_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CountSemGetInfo_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, OS_count_sem_prop_t *count_prop)
{
    int                                 sval;
    OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_count_sem_table, *token);

    if (sem_getvalue(&impl->id, &sval) < 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    /* put the info into the structure */
    count_prop->value = sval;
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No explicit compiler language extensions are used in the provided code fragment. The code uses standard C constructs: local variable declarations, pointer dereference (*token), a macro invocation (OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET), a POSIX API call (sem_getvalue), structure member access (count_prop->value), and integer return codes. None of these are language extensions such as inline assembly, GNU attributes or keywords (e.g. __attribute__, __builtin_*, typeof, statement expressions, asm), compiler-specific storage-class specifiers, or other documented compiler extensions.

Note: The macro OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET and the typedefs (e.g., int32, OS_object_token_t) are not shown; a macro invocation or typedef name alone is not a language extension. If the macro or the typedefs expand to or are implemented using compiler-specific extensions, those expansions would need to be inspected — but based on the visible code there is no evidence of a language extension that must be reported under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
